                                            • Exercise 3.D

                                            1

                                            Suppose T∈L(U,V) and S∈L(V,W) are both invertible linear maps. Prove that ST∈L(U,W) is invertible and (ST)−1=T−1S−1.

                                            Proof: We have

                                            (T−1S−1)(ST)=T−1(S−1S)T=T−1T=IST(T−1S−1)=S(TT−1)S−1=SS−1=I

                                            2

                                            Suppose V is finite-dimensional and dim⁡V>1. Prove that the set of noninvertible operators on V is not a subspace of L(V).

                                            Proof: Let v1,…,vn be a basis of V, Let S and T be elements in L(V) such that

                                            S(a1v1+⋯+anvn)=a1v1T(a1v1+⋯+anvn)=a2v2+⋯+anvn

                                            Since n>1, both S and T are not surjective, thus not invertible, however we can easily see that S+T=I.

                                            3

                                            Suppose V is finite-dimensional, U is a subspace of V and S∈L(U,V). Prove there exists an invertible operator T∈L(V) such that Tu=Su for every u∈U if and only if S is injective.

                                            Proof: For one direction, if there exists an invertible operator T∈L(V) such that Tu=Su for every u∈U, let u1,u2∈U, then

                                            Su1=Su2⟹Tu1=Tu2⟹T−1Tu1=T−1Tu2⟹u1=u2

                                            thus S is injective. Conversely, if S is injective, choose a basis of U to be u1,…,un, extend it to a basis of V by adding v1,…,vm to the original list u1,…,un. Let a1,…,an be scalars such that a1Su1+⋯+anSun=0, then we have a1u1+⋯+anun=0 since S is injective, and thus a1=⋯=an=0 since u1,…,un is linearly independent, thus Su1,…,Sun is linearly independent, extend it to a basis of V by adding w1,…,wm to the list. Now define T∈L(V) by

                                            T(c1u1+⋯+cnun+cn+1v1+⋯+cn+mvm)=c1Su1+⋯+cnSun+cn+1w1+⋯+cn+mwm

                                            for scalars c1,…,cn+m.

                                            For any u∈U, we have u=b1u1+⋯+bnun for some scalars b1,…,bn, thus

                                            Tu=T(b1u1+⋯+bnun)=b1Su1+⋯+bnSun=S(b1u1+⋯+bnun)=Su

                                            Finally to see T is invertible, we let T′∈L(V) be defined as

                                            T′(c1Su1+⋯+cnSun+cn+1w1+⋯+cn+mwm)=c1u1+⋯+cnun+cn+1v1+⋯+cn+mvm

                                            then TT′=T′T=I.

                                            4

                                            Suppose W is finite-dimensional and T1,T2∈L(V,W). Prove that null T1=null T2 if and only if there exists an invertible operator S∈L(W) such that T1=ST2.

                                            Proof: For the "if" part, if v∈null T2, then T1v=ST2v=0, so v∈null T1 and null T2⊆null T1, also if u∈null T1, then T1u=0=ST2u, thus

                                            0=S−10=S−1ST2u=T2u⟹u∈null T2

                                            which means null T1⊆null T2.

                                            For the "only if" part, suppose we have T1v=w≠0 for some v∈V, then T2v≠0, vise versa. Since range T2 is a subspace of W, we can find a basis of the subspace range T2 to be w1,…,wm, and W is finite-dimensional means we can extend this list to a basis of W to be w1,…,wn, thus n≥m and wm+1,…,wn does not belong to range T2. We select v1,…,vm∈V such that T2vi=wi for i=1,…,m. Consider the list T1v1,…,T1vm, we have

                                            a1T1v1+⋯+amT1vm=0⟹T1(a1v1+⋯+amvm)=0⟹a1v1+⋯+amvm∈null T1=null T2⟹T2(a1v1+⋯+amvm)=0⟹a1w1+⋯+amwm=0⟹a1=⋯=am=0

                                            so T1v1,…,T1vm is linearly independent in W, thus can be extended to a basis of W by adding um+1,…,wn​. If v∈V, then T2v∈range T2, so

                                            T2v=c1w1+⋯+cmwm,c1,…,cm∈F

                                            and we have T2v=c1T2v1+⋯+cmT2vm, so c1v1+⋯+cmvm−v belongs to null T2, which means T1v=c1T1v1+⋯+cmT1vm.

                                            Define S to be the function from W to W by

                                            S(c1w1+⋯+cnwn)=c1T1v1+⋯+cmT1vm+cm+1um+1+⋯+cnun

                                            S is a linear map, and for any v∈V, either T2v=0, which gives T1v=0 and ST2v=0, or T2v≠0, then T2v=c1w1+⋯+cmwm, thus

                                            ST2v=S(c1w1+⋯+cmwm)=c1Tv1+⋯+cmT1vm=T1v

                                            5

                                            Suppose V is finite-dimensional and T1,T2∈L(V,W). Prove that range T1=range T2 if and only if there exists an invertible operator S∈L(V) such that T1=T2S.

                                            Proof: For the "if" part, let w∈range T1, then ∃v∈V such that T1v=w, which means T2Sv=T1v=w, thus w∈range T2 and range T1⊆range T2. Conversely, if w∈range T2, then T2v=w for some v∈V, thus

                                            T1(S−1v)=(T2S)(S−1v)=T2(SS−1)v=w

                                            so w∈range T1 and range T2⊆range T1.

                                            For the "only if" part, V is finite-dimensional means range T1 and range T2 are finite dimensional, choose v1,…,vm to be a basis of null T1, expanding the list v1,…,vm to a basis of V, namely v1,…,vn with n≥m, then T1vm+1,…,T1vn is a basis of range T1, thus a basis of range T2. Find um+1,…,un in V such that

                                            T2um+1=T1vm+1,…,T2un=T1vn

                                            if we choose u1,…,um in V to be a basis of null T2, and let ∑i=1nciui=0, then we have

                                            ∑i=1nciui=0⟹∑i=m+1nciui=0⟹T2(∑i=m+1nciui)=∑i=m+1nciT2ui=∑i=m+1nciT1vi=0⟹cm+1=⋯=cn=0⟹∑i=mnciui=0⟹c1=⋯=cm=0

                                            which means u1,…,un is a basis of V. Define S:V→V by

                                            S(a1v1+⋯+anvn)=a1u1+⋯+anun

                                            then S is invertible since the two list are all bases of V, and if v=∑1naivi, we have

                                            T2Sv=T2S(∑i=1naivi)=T2(∑i=1naiui)=∑i=1maiT2ui+∑i=m+1naiT2ui=∑i=m+1naiT1vi=∑i=1naiT1vi=T1v

                                            6

                                            Suppose V and W are finite-dimensional and T1,T2∈L(V,W). Prove that there exist invertible operators R∈L(V) and S∈L(W) such that T1=ST2R if and only if dim⁡null T1=dim⁡null T2.

                                            Proof: For the "if" part, suppose v1,…,vm is a basis for null T1, expanding to a basis v1,…,vn of V, suppose u1,…,um is a basis for null T2, expanding to a basis u1,…,un of V, let R:V→V be defined by Rvi=ui for i=1,…,n, then it is easy to see that T1 and T2R has the same null space, then use Exercise 4.

                                            For the "only if" part, suppose dim⁡null T1=m and v1,…,vm is a basis for null T1, then T1vi=0 means T2Rvi=0 since S is injective, thus Rv1,…,Rvm all belongs to null T2, from the linear independence of v1,…,vm we can deduce the linear independence of Rv1,…,Rvm, which means dim⁡null T2≥m. Similarly, use T2=S−1T1R−1 we can have dim⁡null T1≥dim⁡null T2, and the conclusion follows.

                                            7

                                            Suppose V and W are finite-dimensional. Let v∈V. Let E={T∈L(V,W):Tv=0}.

                                            (a) Show that E is a subspace of L(V,W).

                                            (b) Suppose v≠0. What is dim⁡E?

                                            Solution:

                                            (a) Let T1,T2∈E, then (T1+T2)v=T1v+T2v=0 and (λT1)v=λ(T1v)=0.

                                            (b) Let dim⁡V=n and dim⁡W=m, expanding v to a basis v,v2,…,vn of V, any T∈L(V,W) with Tv=0 corresponds to a m×n matrix with the first column all zero. Thus dim⁡E=m(n−1).

                                            8

                                            Suppose V is finite-dimensional and T:V→W is a surjective linear map of V onto W. Prove that there is a subspace U of V such that T|U is an isomorphism of U onto W.

                                            Proof: We have dim⁡W=dim⁡range T≤dim⁡V, so W is also finite dimensional. Let w1,…,wn be a basis of W, and choose v1,…,vn in V such that Tvi=wi for i=1,…,n, let U be the subspace spanned by v1,…,vn. It only remains to show T|U is injective on U. Let u=c1v1+⋯+cnvn be a vector in U such that Tu=0, then

                                            0=Tu=T(∑i=1ncivi)=∑i=1nciTvi=∑i=1nciwi⟹c1=⋯=cn=0

                                            thus u=0 and T is injective on U.

                                            9

                                            Suppose V is finite-dimensional and S,T∈L(V). Prove that ST is invertible if and only if both S and T are invertible.

                                            Proof: both S and T are invertible can easily lead to ST being invertible. Conversely, if ST is invertible, then S is surjective and T is injective, since V is finite-dimensional, we have dim⁡null S=dim⁡V−dim⁡range S=0, thus S is also injective, and invertible. Similarly T is invertible.

                                            10

                                            Suppose V is finite-dimensional and S,T∈L(V). Prove that ST=I if and only if TS=I.

                                            Proof: Let ST=I, then ST is invertbile, so both S and T are invertible by Exercise 9, thus we have S−1=S−1ST=T, so TS=S−1S=I. A similar proof can be proved given TS=I.

                                            11

                                            Suppose V is finite-dimensional and S,T,U∈L(V) and STU=I. Show that T is invertible and that T−1=US.

                                            Proof: Use Exercise 9, we know that STU is invertible means ST is invertible and U is invertible, and ST is invertible means S and T are invertible. From

                                            S−1U−1=S−1IU−1=S−1(STU)U−1=(S−1S)T(UU−1)=T

                                            we can have

                                            T(US)=S−1U−1US=I,(US)T=USS−1U−1=I

                                            by the definition and uniqueness of T−1, we have T−1=US.

                                            12

                                            Show that the result in the previous exercise can fail without the hypothesis that V is finite-dimensional.

                                            Solution: Let V=F∞, and define

                                            U(x1,x2,…)=(0,0,x1,x2,…)T(x1,x2,x3,…)=(x2,x3,…)S=T

                                            then we can verify that STU=I on V, but T is not invertible since T is not injective by T(1,0,0,…)=0.

                                            13

                                            Suppose V is finite-dimensional and R,S,T∈L(V) are such that RST is surjective. Prove that S is injective.

                                            Proof: That RST is surjective means R is surjective, thus invertible. Let any v∈V, then Rv∈V, so we can find u∈V such that RSTu=Rv, which means R−1(RSTu)=R−1(Rv) or v=STu, thus S is surjective, and the conclusion follows from 3.69, injectivity is equivalent to surjectivity.

                                            14

                                            Suppose v1,…,vn is a basis of V. Prove that the map T:V→Fn,1 defined by Tv=M(v) is an isomorphism of V onto Fn,1; here M(v) is the matrix of v∈V with respect to the basis v1,…,vn.

                                            Proof: Let (c1,…,cn) be any element in Fn,1, then the vector v=∑i=1ncivi satisfies the equation M(v)=(c1,…,cn), thus T is surjective. Suppose there is u∈V such that Tu=0∈Fn,1, then it means M(u)=(0,…,0), so u=0, thus T is injective.

                                            15

                                            Prove that every linear map from Fn,1 to Fm,1 is given by a matrix multiplication. In other words, prove that if T∈L(Fn,1,Fm,1), then there exists an m-by-n matrix A such that Tx=Ax for every x∈Fn,1.

                                            Proof: Let V and W be any finite-dimensional vector space such that dim⁡V=n and dim⁡W=m, suppose v1,…,vn is a basis of V and w1,…,wm is a basis of W, let Rv=M(v),v∈V and Sw=M(w),w∈W be defined as Exercise 14, then R is an isomorphism of V onto Fn,1 and S is an isomorphism of W onto Fm,1. For any v∈V, we have Rv∈Fn,1, so TRv∈Fm,1 and S−1(TRv)∈W. Let

                                            A=M(S−1TR,(v1,…,vn),(w1,…,wm))

                                            for every x=(x1,…,xn)∈Fn,1, let v=x1v1+⋯+xnvn, then Rv=x, and Tx=TRv=y=(y1,…,ym)∈Fm,1, which means S−1y=y1w1+⋯+ymwm, let w=y1w1+⋯+ymwm, then we have

                                            Tx=y=M(w)=M(S−1TRv)=M(S−1TR)M(v)=Ax

                                            16

                                            Suppose V is finite-dimensional and T∈L(V). Prove that T is a scalar multiple of the identity if and only if ST=TS for every S∈L(V).

                                            Proof: The "only if" part is obvious, let T=aI for some scalar a, then

                                            ST=S(aI)=aS=(aI)S=TS,S∈L(V)

                                            For the "if" part, let v1,…,vn be a basis of V, let S1 be the linear map such that

                                            S1(c1v1+⋯+cnvn)=c1v1

                                            suppose Tv1=a1v1+⋯+anvn, then S1Tv1=a1v1 and TS1v1=Tv1, we can have a2v2+⋯+anvn=0 and a2=⋯=an=0, so Tv1=a1v1 for some scalar a1. Similarly we can prove Tvi=aivi for i=1,…,n.

                                            Let S be the linear map such that S(c1v1+⋯+cnvn)=c1v2, then

                                            STv1=S(a1v1)=a1v2,TSv1=Tv2=a2v2

                                            which gives a1=a2, similarly we can prove ai=aj for i,j=1,…,n.

                                            17

                                            Suppose V is finite-dimensional and E is a subspace of L(V) such that ST∈E and TS∈E for all S∈L(V) and all T∈E. Prove that E={0} or E=L(V).

                                            Proof: Let dim⁡V=n. That E={0} can satisfy the given requirements, suppose E≠{0}, then there is some T∈E such that T≠0, this means we can find v∈V such that Tv=w≠0. Expand v and w to a basis of V respectively, i.e. we can have basis v,v2,…,vn and w,w2,…,wn of V. Then

                                            M(T,(v,v2,…,vn),(w,w2,…,wn))=(10⋯000⋯0⋯⋯00⋯0)

                                            Let eij denote the matrix with all elements zero except 1 at the ith row and the jth column, then M(T)=e11, let S be the linear map with the corresponding matrix be the identity matrix interchanging the first two rows, i.e.

                                            M(S,(v,v2,…,vn),(w,w2,…,wn))=(01⋯010⋯0⋯⋯00⋯1)

                                            then we have M(ST)=e21 and M(TS)=e12. Since L(V) and Fn,n are isomorphic, let E be the subspace of Fn,n which is isomorphic to E, then e21∈E and e12∈E, similarly we can prove ek1∈E and e1k∈E for k=1,…,n. By the same logic we can further prove ejk∈E for j=2,…,n by letting A the identity matrix interchanging row 1 and row j, then use Ae1k=ejk, and prove ekj∈E for j=2,…,n by letting A the identity matrix interchanging column 1 and column j, then use ekj=ek1A. Since eij∈E for i,j=1,…,n, we have E=Fn,n and E=L(V).

                                            18

                                            Show that V and L(F,V) are isomorphic vector spaces.

                                            Proof: For v∈V, define Tv:F→V to be Tv(1)=v, then Tv(a)=av, we have Tv(a+b)=(a+b)v=av+bv=Tv(a)+Tv(b) and Tv(ka)=kav=kTv(a), thus Tv is a linear map. So we can define the map T:V→L(F,V) by Tv=Tv.

                                            We first show T is linear. Let v,w∈V, then T(v+w)=Tv+w is a linear map such that Tv+w(1)=v+w, thus

                                            Tv+w(a)=a(v+w)=av+aw=Tv(a)+Tw(a),∀a∈F

                                            which means T(v+w)=Tv+Tw. Similarly we can have T(λv)=Tλv a linear map such that Tλv(1)=λv, thus

                                            Tλv(a)=aλv=λav=λTv(a),∀a∈F

                                            which means T(λv)=λTv.

                                            If Tv=0, then Tv(1)=0, by definition we see v=0. Let S∈L(F,V), then S(1)∈V, Consider TS(1), we have TS(1)(1)=S(1), and for a∈F we have S(a)=aS(1)=aTS(1)(1)=TS(1)(a), thus TS(1)=S. This means T is injective and surjective, thus invertible, and the conclusion follows.

                                            19

                                            Suppose T∈L(P(R)) is such that T is injective and deg⁡Tp≤deg⁡p for every nonzero polynomial p∈P(R).

                                            (a) Prove that T is surjective.

                                            (b) Prove that deg⁡Tp=deg⁡p for every nonzero p∈P(R).

                                            Proof:

                                            (a) Consider P1(F), let p(z)=a∈P1(F) with a≠0, then deg⁡Tp≤deg⁡p=0, which means deg⁡Tp=0 or deg⁡Tp=−∞, the latter means Tp=0, a contradiction to T being injective, thus deg⁡Tp=0 and Tp=b∈P1(F), thus P1(F)⊆span (Tp) with p∈P1(F). Suppose we already have Pm−1(F)⊆span (Tp), with p∈Pm−1(F) and m≥2, let p(z)=zm, then deg⁡Tp≤m, but deg⁡Tp<m means Tp∈Pm−1(F), which means we can find p′∈Pm−1(F) such that Tp=Tp′ or T(p−p′)=0, since deg⁡p=m and deg⁡p′≤m−1, we see p−p′≠0, this is a contradiction to T being injective. Thus we must have deg⁡Tp=m, which means Pm(F)⊆span (Tp), with p∈Pm(F). Since it is true for all integers m, T is surjective.

                                            (b) Let p be any nonzero polynomial, let deg⁡p=m, assume deg⁡Tp<m, then Tp∈Pm−1(F). The proof in (a) shows that Pm−1(F)⊆span (Tq), with q∈Pm−1(F), so Tq=Tp and T(q−p)=0, since q−p≠0, this contradicts T being injective. Thus deg⁡Tp=m.

                                            20

                                            Suppose n is a positive integer and Ai,j∈F for i,j=1,…,n. Prove that the following are equivalent (note that in both parts below, the number of equations equals the number of variables):

                                            (a) The trivial solution x1=⋯=xn=0 is the only solution to the homogeneous system of equations

                                            ∑k=1nA1,kxk=0⋮∑k=1nAn,kxk=0

                                            (b) For every c1,…,cn∈F, there exists a solution to the system of equations

                                            ∑k=1nA1,kxk=c1⋮∑k=1nAn,kxk=cn

                                            Proof: Define

                                            A=[A1,1⋯A1,n⋮⋮An,1⋯An,n]

                                            Select a vector space V with dim⁡V=n, since L(V) and Fm,n are isomorphic, there exist T∈L(V) such that for some basis v1,…,vn of V, we have M(T)=A. Define v=x1v1+⋯+xnvn, then we have M(Tv)=M(T)M(v), while

                                            M(T)M(v)=[A1,1⋯A1,n⋮⋮An,1⋯An,n][x1⋮xn]=[∑k=1nA1,kxk⋮∑k=1nAn,kxk]

                                            thus (a) is equivalent to say that v=0 is the only solution for Tv=0, or T is injective. (b) is equivalent to say that for every v∈V, there exists some vector u such that Tu=v, or T is surjective. By 3.69, the two are equivalent.
